Cross-allergies between respiratory and food allergens can be explained by the ''recognition, by a patient's specific IgE antibodies'', of '''similar'' or highly homologous allergens present in '''distinct allergenic sources'' (respiratory and food).

The most common clinical picture is that of an "oral syndrome" (labial or lingual oedema, oral or pharyngeal pruritus, labial, lingual or palatal erythema) after eating fruit in a patient with a pollen allergy.


For example: - birch, apple and other raw fruit and vegetable pollens ;

- cypress, peach and sometimes citrus pollens.

- egg-bird syndrome (induction of egg allergy by the respiratory route by feathers or bird droppings);

question.title: What is the most common clinical picture in a patient with a pollen allergy who also eats fruit?
question.description: A multiple-choice question about the clinical presentation of cross-allergies

option_a.title: Labial or lingual erythema and oral pruritus after eating nuts
option_a.description: A plausible but incorrect answer that could be tempting for someone who doesn't know the correct answer

option_b.title: Labial or lingual oedema, oral or pharyngeal pruritus, labial, lingual or palatal erythema after eating fruit
option_b.description: The correct answer based on the provided text

option_c.title: Induction of egg allergy by the respiratory route by feathers or bird droppings
option_c.description: A distractor that is related to the topic but not relevant to the question

option_d.title: A rare condition where a patient has an allergy to both food and respiratory allergens
option_d.description: A distractor that is not mentioned in the provided text

correct_option.title: B
correct_option.description: The letter of the correct option
